title: Ticket #6729: memory leak in submitMany python binding
description:
FNAL reports that the submitMany python binding is leaking memory. Their own ticket for this is https://github.com/dmwm/WMCore/issues/8493. This ticket indicates the problem is with 8.5.7, but we have email from them indicating that the problem reproduces on 8.6.11 and 8.7.7.

They have provided a script for reproducing the problem here https://github.com/amaltaro/ProductionTools/blob/master/testCondorSubmission.py
remarks:
2018-Aug-01 17:29:36 by tannenba:
Possible workaround:

Using submitMany() is a pain in the rear. It is a lot easier to to submit jobs via the htcondor.Submit() object, and (hopefully!) this does not suffer the memory leak bug. htcondor.Submit() uses the same key/value pairs that you would use in a regular condor_submit file, so no need to come up with a classad for the job. Example of submitting a 100 jobs (procs) into one cluster : 

import htcondor
sub = htcondor.Submit()
# Specify executable
sub['Executable']='Example.exe'
# Specify a custom attribute - use the '+' just like a submit file
sub['+MyCustomAttribute']='True'
# Specify arguments, using $(Process) like a submit file
sub['Arguments']='-run_number $(Process)'
# Send 100 jobs into a cluster
with schedd.transaction() as txn:
  sub.queue(txn,100)

2018-Aug-07 10:45:54 by johnkn:
I did some investigation, it's leaking the classAds that are returned by submitMany via the 4th argument. But only if you don't supply the 4th argument. Not really sure why this is so, but you can easily work around the bug just by calling submitMany with 4 arguments like this: 

    submitMany(clusterAd, procAds, 0, [])

2018-Aug-07 13:43:23 by johnkn:
actually 

  schedd.submitMany(clusterAd, procAds, 0, None)

Is better, because None causes the creation of the result_ads to be skipped entirely.

2018-Oct-08 15:13:19 by tlmiller:
Code Review

Although it doesn't show up in the commit, in submitMany() we explicitly check for and handle the case that ad_results is not a list. submit() turns around and calls submitMany() without even looking at ad_results, so that should be fine, too.

Approved. Documentation looks good as well.
